body: Confused, why do you have two CreateMaps?
Alright @jbogard, I removed the second call. But this doesn't really change anything.
This is still relevant. Any news?

I think this would be pretty confusing, to have member mappings "actually" map to constructor argument configuration. Instead, I would imagine something similar to ForMember for constructor arguments:

```
Mapper.CreateMap<Src, Dest>()
    .ForCtorParam("resolvedVal", opt => opt.MapFrom(src => src.Val)));
```

@jbogard: ~~Isn't it like that (member mappings also being used for ctor arguments) already? It's only while the ctor is _checked for eligibility_ that the mappings aren't considered.~~

~~I.e., current situation:~~
- ~~while AutoMapper checks whether a destination ctor can be used, the parameters must correspond to source properties;~~
- ~~during the actual resolution, AutoMapper instead uses member mappings to resolve the destination ctor parameters.~~

(**Updated 2014-12-26:** I was wrong and confused, see below.)

I think that using member mappings for both steps would definitely improve the situation. I also don't think it's too confusing - it's pretty standard to have a 1:1 mapping between properties and ctors in a DTO anyway. And it's safe for refactoring, too.

One thought is, coordinate that with your favorite Dependency Injection container? Several of them that I know of have some way to decorate parameters such that you could connect the dots with an AutoMapper resource.

I agree with everything @fschmied has said. Also I think, whatever other arguments could speak against using the same API for constructor injections, one should decide for convenience here. Does it matter if it's set through property or constructor? I'm not really interested in that distinction.

@jbogard Sorry, I just checked and noticed that I was wrong earlier. AutoMapper appears to _always_ use name-based mapping (only) for constructor parameters. I.e., the value for a destination ctor argument "x" sems to always be taken directly from a source property "x" or "X", ignoring any ForMember mappings. I was confused by the fact that the member mapping is _additionally_ executed if the property has any setter, even private. Therefore, my statement about an inconsistency already existing between the ctor eligibility check and the ctor invocation was incorrect.

Now, about whether to also use ForMember for ctor parameters or not. I think the most important point is that we need some way to customize ctor parameter mappings, for the same reasons why we need to customize property mappings. If this need is undisputed, then the approach that you (@jbogard) suggested can always be used and it always works correctly, no matter how the properties are implemented:

```
Mapper.CreateMap<Src, Dest>()
    .ForCtorParam("resolvedVal", opt => opt.MapFrom(src => src.Val)));
```

Since this is probably the best solution that always works, it is of course what AutoMapper should implement first. Unfortunately, this solution suffers from the big drawback of having to reference the ctor parameter as a string, with no compiler or tooling (refactoring) support at all (although you can detect errors while building the map). That's a pity, but for the general solution, I don't think it can be helped [^1].

However, what about the (many) DTO scenarios, where objects are just plain data containers and properties really do match ctor parameter names? Couldn't AutoMapper allow me, as a programmer knowing that my objects follow my conventions, allow me to specify my ctor argument mappings by convention, too?

```
Mapper.CreateMap<Src, Dest>()
    .ForCtorParamMatching(src => src.ResolvedVal, opt => opt.MapFrom(src => src.Val)));
```

With the other feature already in place, this would of course be trivial to implement (just use the member name as a string), while giving me refactoring and tooling support. But only if I choose to use it.

What do you think?

[^1] For completeness' sake, here's an alternative that's also compiler-supported and refactoring-safe:

```
Mapper.CreateMap<Src, Dest>()
    .ConstructUsing(opt => new Dest (opt.MapFrom(src => src.Val)));
```

However, I don't like it because it is so verbose - it requires me to mention every single ctor parameter, even those I don't want to explicitly specify (e.g., using an `opt.MapDefault<int>()` method or something like that), it's more difficult to implement, and it doesn't fit AutoMapper's general API very well.

Some good arguments here.  I agree with the ForCtorParamMatching suggestion put forward by @fschmied - the more correct .ForCtorParam() can be present and the more tool-friendly (but possibly incorrect) .ForCtorParamMatching() method available for those who know what they're doing and wish to opt in to potentially incorrect behaviour.  
As someone just getting started with AutoMapper I'd like to use it with the https://github.com/AArnott/ImmutableObjectGraph library that I've been using for quite some time.  That brings its own problems since the constructors are private (there's a static Create() factory method instead) but I've succesfully written JSON.Net converter contract classes and I'd like to do the same for AutoMapper when I get time.
@jbogard  Why is this issue closed? Did you decide against the suggestion put forward by @fschmied?

@chrischu I dunno, it was 3-4 years ago. I can't remember issues closed last week!

Feel free to open a new issue for a feature request. We can have a more targeted discussion then.
